Award.AwardTitle: Regularity Problems in the Calculus of Variations and Elliptic Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on central problems in classical fields such as the calculus of variations and free boundary problems. Some problems find their motivation in the applied sciences and therefore offer opportunities for collaborations among mathematicians and other researchers. For example, the so-called "one-phase problem" describes the motion of a fluid in which a cavity is present that is a mixture of vapor and gas and the pressure on the cavity is constant. Other problems under investigation are related to issues of optimal transportation and allocation of resources. All such problems require the development of new sophisticated techniques, and progress will be disseminated to the scientific community to invigorate the advancement of the theory.

The PI will study the classification of cones in low dimensions for the "one-phase" free boundary problem. As a tool in the analysis of free boundaries, the PI will investigate some boundary Harnack type results. In the context of optimal transportation, the PI is interested in the higher regularity for a class of degenerate Monge-Ampere equations in which the right hand side vanishes on the boundary. Finally, parts of this project deal with the fundamental question of local regularity of minimizers in the calculus of variations. In particular, in the scalar case the PI will investigate situations in which the integrand becomes highly degenerate on some compact set. In the vectorial case, the PI plans to construct some interesting singular minimizers in low dimensions and will also explore a viscosity approach to regularity for certain types of functionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on developing new regularity techniques in various PDE problems of elliptic type which arise in the calculus of variations, geometry and free boundary problems. 

The PI established novel methods in several directions. Motivated by the theory of almost minimizers from the calculus of variations, the PI in collaboration with De Silva developed a viscosity solution theory for approximate solutions that do not necessarily satisfy an equation at infinitesimal scale. This approach turned out to be successful in various other problems:

1) the theory of almost minimizers for the area functional developed by Almgren and Tamanini

2) the theory of nonlocal phase transitions where the rigidity of global solutions with asymptoticaly flat level sets was established for nonlocal semilinear equations.

3) regularity of the free boundary in Bernoulli type problems for almost minimizers of the one-phase functional, and the thin one-phase functional.

In another direction, the PI established fine regularity properties at the boundary for graphical nonlocal minimal surfaces. He also extended the notion of fractional operators for functions that have any polynomial growth at infinity. This becomes very useful when performing a blow-up analysis in problems involving integro-differential equations. 

In another project, the PI investigated the boundary regularity for various degenerate Monge-Ampere type equations under sharp conditions of the data. These equations are relevant for example in the study of affine spheres in geometry, the p-Minkowski problem, or in optimal transportation problems involving two densities with only one of them having compact support.

The results achieved in this project have been disseminated to the scientific community through participation to conferences and seminars. They also opened up several future directions of research.
